text: I think if you’re motivated enough you can measure whatever you want. Most people just ‘vibe it’ when it comes to brand/awareness campaigns but you can certainly measure brand mentions, brand searches, social media metrics and in some cases increase sales (for b2c or high velocity/self-serve b2b). One thing you need to establish early on is how the funnel looks like for each campaign - is the brand campaign the beginning of the funnel, leading to other content nurturing/BDR follow up or an end-to-end campaign on its own. Basically what are you expecting to get out of the campaign (just a next step in the cycle or an SQL/ sale?) - and make sure you’re not running a campaign measuring social media followers or traffic while the boss is expecting more demo requests, etc.

Basically what are you expecting to get out of the campaign (just a next step in the cycle or an SQL/ sale?) - and make sure you’re not running a campaign measuring social media followers or traffic while the boss is expecting more demo requests, etc.

text:
Have any of you done any targets/results projections based on incoming new hires?
We’re looking at expanding our content team from 1 to 4 people and I was asked to show how our outputs and performance (traffic, MQL, SEO) will grow over time as more people come on board. Outputs is easy but the performance bit I find it a bit of a random guess. My intuition is to take into account the “natural growth” if I continue working alone (this is already a lot of guesswork) and then add accelerated growth when new people come onboard while taking into account those people will need training and I will move from IC to managing (more guessing). One of them will also be working things I’m not currently working on (focusing on original long-form content) so I have no benchmark/historical data on the performance (i.e. how long-form content will affect our MQL number). Do people usually just make assumptions? Like if natural growth is 20% (team of 1), adding two people would mean we’ll grow by 60% (team of 3)? It seems totally random to me. this is out of my comfort zone and I’m getting a bit lost in my spreadsheets. Any insights are highly appreciated.

elements.text:
Have any of you done any targets/results projections based on incoming new hires?
We’re looking at expanding our content team from 1 to 4 people and I was asked to show how our outputs and performance (traffic, MQL, SEO) will grow over time as more people come on board. Outputs is easy but the performance bit I find it a bit of a random guess. My intuition is to take into account the “natural growth” if I continue working alone (this is already a lot of guesswork) and then add accelerated growth when new people come onboard while taking into account those people will need training and I will move from IC to managing (more guessing). One of them will also be working things I’m not currently working on (focusing on original long-form content) so I have no benchmark/historical data on the performance (i.e. how long-form content will affect our MQL number). Do people usually just make assumptions? Like if natural growth is 20% (team of 1), adding two people would mean we’ll grow by 60% (team of 3)? It seems totally random to me. this is out of my comfort zone and I’m getting a bit lost in my spreadsheets. Any insights are highly appreciated.

text:
What you're describing is a growth model (might help you find more information). Basically you want a spreadsheet that models out the next 12-18 months of key metrics you've identified -- like traffic and MQLs.

As you described, I would do a spreadsheet that shows expected growth w/ 1 person and then another tab showing accelerated growth with a larger team.

But you don't just want to show that number making a big jump :slightly_smiling_face: Keep outlining your assumptions in the spreadsheet. For example, you mentioned a focus on long-form content. Do you know the keywords those pages would focus on? What is the current MSV of that cluster? What % of MSV would you like to claim? Then you can start putting in numbers that aren't just assumptions. Your growth model could actually show you targeting specific keyword clusters.

You could potentially get very detailed here :slightly_smiling_face: But it takes you out of pure assumption land.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: I think it's fair to outline growth for the next quarter, or 6 months. With content, it's a bit more straightforward because you can project a content plan that requires more people and focus on the results of the plan, versus the people.

elements.text: I think it's fair to outline growth for the next quarter, or 6 months. With content, it's a bit more straightforward because you can project a content plan that requires more people and focus on the results of the plan, versus the people.

text: Most companies I know have no real idea how content interacts with MQLs, never mind actual business results. Even with a poor attribution model (first click or last click are both pretty bad, and W-attribution is preferred, but not easy to set up), you should be able to have some idea the influence content has had (even if its just the stuff you see in GA).

elements.text: Most companies I know have no real idea how content interacts with MQLs, never mind actual business results. text: Not sure if this is what you mean but there’s the 10/50/90 rule which I like. There’s several iterations of it and it can be adjusted for creative feedback. You can read one example here: <https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/why-105090-rule-make-you-better-consultant-manager-michael-navarrete|https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/why-105090-rule-make-you-better-consultant-manager-michael-navarrete>

attachments.title: Why the 10/50/90 Rule will make you a Better Consultant and Manager
attachments.text: Introduction Welcome to the one single rule that every manager should teach (and every employee should know). The 10/50/90 Rule is a simple framework designed to help smooth the task management (read: communication) process in between a Task giver and Task receiver.
attachments.fallback: Why the 10/50/90 Rule will make you a Better Consultant and Manager

text: Hey, everyone! I’m about to launch a re-design of my company’s blog. It was designed before there was a marketing team, isn’t optimized for SEO, and in general needs some love. Although we redesigned our website in the last couple of months, I left the blog as it’s own special project as it’s a big content channel for us. I’m looking for inspo…some of your favorite blogs, some tips to keep in mind when going through this process, wordpress plugins you love…anything! Thanks in advance :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
For 1500 word articles, I outline most of it and find good research to start. i also add initial keywords and have been adding in Clearscope terms lately.

This takes about an hour. My reviews are usually faster, b/c I'm doing grammatical changes myself and only ask for big revisions.

Formatting and all of that takes the bulk of my time or the team's time.

text: Curious as to the context/what you mean…do you mean giving creatives direction on their projects? feedback they need to be more creative?

elements.text: Curious as to the context/what you mean…do you mean giving creatives direction on their projects? feedback they need to be more creative?

text: I mean giving feedback to designers

elements.text: I mean giving feedback to designers

text:
ah. i find the best approach is learning technical terms they already use. Like understanding how to talk about contrast, balance, repetition (for cleanliness), whitespace, etc. When you can bring that to the table, you’ll have a better go, so it;s worth learning about on your own. (Google searches on this provide tons of basic/intro guides to design terms and concepts)

Also pin-point what’s not working. If something looks busy, you say “there’s a lot of visual elements here. what do we want people to focus on the most?” vs just saying “busy” (which is a sliding/personal scale for most of us). If it’s too bland to you, (again, subjective) say “This is very clean, but I wonder if we could give it some more visual interest somehow, it would stand out more? For example, could the background have more texture, the fonts/headline bolder.brighter?”

I usually try to take my initial reaction (this is too busy, too bland, to colourful, etc.) and then break down a few elements that illustrate my point. My steps are 1. Pin point how you feel, 2. try to explain it without bias/as much subjectivity, and 3. try to pick some specific elements you think they could change to get there so they really get what you mean.

I also try to point out where I could have done a better job with where I wanted the emphasis to be in the piece or project (did i specify an h1? givec strong direction on the purpose?) That way it’s not all on them.  “Oh i see you took this in a super profesional direction. We actually want this to be more fun. I could have tweaked the copy to reflect that more or communicated it to you better I think.” (Doesn’t hurt to admit you have a role to play, esp. if it’s a young designer or they’re kinda on the stubborn end.)

Always do it on a call if it’s complex or a lot of feedback. Writing it out leaves WAY too mjuch room for interpretation and will probably cause you to go back and forth more than you like (and frustrate everyone).

Finally-*-find an example of what you want or mean if you can. B*eing able to hold up a visual and examples to show what your talking about reduces the issues with interpreting what “bold” “bright” or “sublte” means to you. this visual reference will help the designer get your taste level.

Hope a few of those tips are helpful! Good luck.

text:
Anyone have a better word for “resources”? It’s so stuffy and jargony. The problem is I’m talking about lots of different content types like webinars, email courses, etc.
> You now have access to member-exclusive resources to help you learn about xyz…

elements.text: Anyone have a better word for “resources”? It’s so stuffy and jargony. The problem is I’m talking about lots of different content types like webinars, email courses, etc.

• Blogs = “Read items”.

text: Also, as a more general comment, I’d say the Library is tough since it’s inherently quite generic given that everything gets put in there. Something you can do longer term is focus your approach around topic hubs – and so instead of a Library you have a bunch of Topic Hubs that are linked to. You still might call it a Library (or whatever), but it’s more directed toward the user’s intent.

elements.text: Also, as a more general comment, I’d say the Library is tough since it’s inherently quite generic given that everything gets put in there. You still might call it a Library (or whatever), but it’s more directed toward the user’s intent.
